p: Dietary fat could provide high energy and essential fatty acid (EFA) to satisfy the rapid growth rate and the requirement of physiological lipid in most cultured fishes [ 1– 5]. Within certain limits, the increase of dietary fat level could improve the utilization of feed [ 6] and protect somehow against the metabolism of protein for energy [ 7, 8], especially in carnivorous fish species. However, high fat diets led to the increased fat deposition in fish body, induced metabolic impairments including fatty liver syndrome [ 9], abnormal oxidative status [ 10], and altered nutritional value, organoleptic and physical properties [ 6]. Many research findings revealed that the variation of dietary fat level must be carefully evaluated as it may affect lipid metabolic strategies and lipid deposit pattern [ 2, 11– 17].
